honestly first you can use the cast on tail of yarn to close that short seam in the starting circle you ll now be working in rounds so you need to mark the start of the first round with a safety pin after the last ridge worked do this after the first couple of ridges i know a spiral doesn t actually have rounds but for the purposes of this pattern we need to impose rounds on it 4 first round ridge 1 k8 w&t k8 ridge 2 k9 join k9 repeat these two ridges all round the circle until you get back to your safety pin alternating short ridges and joined ones helps the circle to lay flat - after a fashion plain rounds from now on you can forget about those shaping short ridges as the rest of the rounds are worked without them to make the knitting curve into something more hat shaped so … work every ridge as a plain joining ridge k9 join k9 move your safety pin over to the new outside ridge to mark the start and end of each round after the first of these plain rounds the knitting will look a bit like a bowl 5 it gets to look more like a hat with each round you complete plain rounds start here i worked four plain rounds for my hat to allow for a folded brim and a big head my hat measured about 25 cm / 10 tall at this point so you might want to work just three rounds for a smaller head or if you don t want a folded brim just try the hat on after every round to check the fit as the knitting is a spiral you need to work a tapering strip of knitting after your last plain round to give the hat a smooth edge finishing it off for a long gradual tapered edge decreasing ridges are inserted after every five normal joined ridges like this ridges 1 -
